This process may explain the missing plastic debris. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of floating plastic debris in the ocean.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors. One of the most prominent is the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This is supposedly shown by a classic experiment published 45 years ago. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time. They are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research. In hindsight, this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The disease is characterized by progressive loss of sensation and disfigurement. The disease is curable with multidrug therapy. However, the disease is still prevalent in some regions of the world. The causative agent of the disease, Mycobacterium lepromatosis, is not known. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a patient in Mexico. We compared the genome with that of M. leprae. We also performed a phylogeographic survey of leprosy patients. We found that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the MRCA of Mycobacterium than is M. leprae. This suggests that M. lepromatosis may be a more recent pathogen.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and the laws of thermodynamics. However, their interplay is not fully understood. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in a generic quantum system can be understood in terms of quasiparticles. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work provides a general framework for the entanglement dynamics. It also opens the way to the computation of the thermodynamics.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353). This is a major step forward in understanding the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is not clear whether brain size is a good proxy for brain power. Here, we show that the evolution of brain power is better understood by analyzing the evolution of the number of neurons. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. We propose that the evolution of brain power should be studied by analyzing the evolution of the number of neurons. This approach is more accurate and unbiased.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. The common cold is the most common viral infection worldwide. The virus that causes most colds is rhinovirus. The COVID-19 pandemic has been characterized by the rapid spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes disease, and the emergence of multiple variants. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. This paper examines the causes of this trend and the problems that are being created. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. It is currently believed that the immune system is activated by amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and subsequent microglial activation. However, this is not the case in all AD models. Here, we show that neurons are also activated by Aβ. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons produce a variety of potent immune factors. These factors correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization. We also show that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent in the brain. This is a significant finding, since the Aβ-burdened neuron is vulnerable to the toxic effects of Aβ. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary target in AD.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our analysis show that the majority of the chicken bones belong to adult individuals. We further show that the frequency of chicken bones in the Southern Levant increased sharply during the Hellenistic period. These results are supported by a survey of chicken bones from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of chicken domestication.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions. We find that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can save 3.61 million lives per year and reduce global warming by 0.51 °C. This would be a major global public health and climate change intervention.

The emergence of plague from its progenitor Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is a well-known story. However, the early history of plague is poorly understood. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years. We present a genome-wide analysis of a late 5th/early 6th century AD population from southern Germany. The analysis of the 41 individuals indicates that men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans. However, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides a unique window into the past and the genetic processes that shaped modern Europe. It also provides a resource for future studies of the genetic history of Europe.

The formation of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater is a first for Mars. Crop condition monitoring is a key tool for agricultural decision-making. Current systems rely on crop models, satellite imagery, and meteorological data. However, these systems have underutilized legacy sources of information such as crop expert surveys. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. Although the crop condition index reflects the subjective perception of many surveyors at different locations, the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed system is simple, low-cost, and scalable. It can be easily replicated in other countries. The data are freely available. The code is open source. The system is ready for use.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain. We show that memory can be supported by changes in the excitability of neurons. These changes are adaptive and can be accessed directly. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order. It is suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a new framework for understanding the neural basis of memory.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa to extreme droughts. We use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of such droughts in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100 under a high-emission scenario. This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is timely, as the Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 °C. It is important to quantify the risk of extreme droughts under different emission scenarios. This work provides a first step in this direction.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases. Neuroinflammation is mediated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes was associated with later-stage neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages exacerbated later-stage neuroinflammation, which subsequently activated astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes is required for the generation and maintenance of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a potential mechanism for neuroinflammation in EAE. It also provides a potential target for neuroinflammation in other neurodegenerative diseases.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. News media are increasingly focused on negative content. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that demonstrates the pervasiveness of negativity biases in news content across the globe. The results also highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. This variation may be a function of individual differences in the way that people process information. In any case, the results help to account for the tendency for news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” The results are based on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the psychophysiological reactions of 1,000 participants to real news video. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation and aggregation of misfolded proteins. These protein aggregates can spread throughout the brain, causing damage to vulnerable neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spread of protein aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active endocytosis. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of protein aggregation in general. This is an important step toward understanding the mechanisms of neurodegenerative disease.

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. Mammalian cells have two SHMT isozymes, SHMT1 and SHMT2. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. The disease is associated with the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies that contain a variety of proteins. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral RNA synthesis. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection is effective in preventing and treating the disease. The data support the development of a clinical trial to test the efficacy of remdesivir in MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance in the fight against the current pandemic.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health. However, the mechanisms by which host-derived nutrients are provisioned to the gut microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. We show that chitin is provided to the symbiont just before dusk, when the squid’s symbiotic organ is at its most stable. We also show that chitin is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the organ’s stability. Finally, we show that catabolism of chitin is required for the acidification of the organ’s crypts, which enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. We propose that this is a general mechanism by which animals provision nutrients to their gut microbiota. This may be a mechanism by which animals control the stability of their symbioses.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study tested whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline could be changed through an online intervention. These findings suggest that suspension rates can be reduced through scalable interventions. This study also provides a scalable, evidence-based approach to improving teacher–student relationships. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe disease. We found that the first cleavages of MERS-CoV S proteins compromised infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The process of meiosis is essential for sexual reproduction, but it is also the most error-prone stage of the cell cycle. This suggests that hotspots may be a conserved mechanism for ensuring accurate meiosis.

The hominin hand is a key to understanding the evolution of modern human form and function. The fossil record for the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from West Turkana, Kenya, that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding also suggests that the evolution of the modern human hand may have begun in the genus Homo. This is an important finding for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the hominin lineage leading to Neandertals and modern humans. The fossil is also the earliest known hominin from Kenya. This is an important finding for understanding the hominin fossil record in East Africa. The fossil is named Kaitio I and is assigned a new species, Australopithecus afarensis kaitioensis. The fossil is assigned a new hominin genus, Ardipithecus. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. Mammalian cells have two SHMT isozymes, SHMT1 and SHMT2. SHMT2 is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2. We show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer. It also provides a rationale for targeting formate dehydrogenase in cancer.

The role of forests in improving people’s diets is not well understood. We show that deforestation in rural Tanzania led to a reduction in people’s fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This approach can be used to test causal hypotheses and to make causal inferences. This is particularly important in the social sciences. We believe that this approach should be used more widely in the social sciences. We hope that this study will encourage others to do so.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
